ygData.subject: Re: New paper "Novelty-based multiobjectivization"
ygData.msgSnippet: Jeff, I agree that the novelty+fitness MOEA has good potential as a practical approach and should be interesting to follow. However, I think there is an

Subject: Re: New paper "Novelty-based multiobjectivization"
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=jzdWYTXtYlxOrapnfW_q_Hj5zfr9EQvb_jphvrXbZ74QFzWj8YCE
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

Jeff, I agree that the novelty+fitness MOEA has good potential as a practic=
al approach and should be interesting to follow.

However, I think there is=
 an important facet of the novelty search results that goes beyond performa=
nce.  The idea that there are "huge classes of problems where pure Novelty =
search will not work" misses that it is a shock that it works in any seriou=
s domains at all!  Would you really expect a method that does not even know=
 what it is looking for to solve *anything* better than fitness-based searc=
h?  Yet in fact we have been accumulating more and more domains where it do=
es better.

Nevertheless, of course there are domains in which it will perf=
orm poorly.  Yet the onus here should not be on novelty search, which does =
not purport to try to solve anything at all.  What I think is more interest=
ing is the embarrassing result that fitness-based search is so inept agains=
t an algorithm that does not even know what it is looking for.  The whole t=
hing is more of an indictment on the way we have been conducting search, an=
d the way we have been interpreting learning algorithm results, than it is =
an endorsement of novelty search as the solution to all problems.  

For ex=
ample, in the past, when fitness-NEAT attempts to solve a problem and fails=
, we would have said the problem is NEAT.  Yet when novelty-NEAT solves the=
 same problem seamlessly, the lie of the original interpretation is reveale=
d.  In fact, there are many negative results for many algorithms that we sh=
ould be questioning in light of novelty search.  We have been assuming that=
 the fitness-based paradigm *is* learning, when it is only a small sliver o=
f what learning can be.  

I also do not think that expanding the maze 100 =
times would cause much problem, besides needing individual evaluations to l=
ast 100 times longer.  But the number of evaluations needed to evolve a sol=
ution would be about the same.  Taking away the walls would cause it to nee=
d more evaluations, but I don't see it really causing a fundamental problem=
.  So I would dispute that it is as brittle as you say.

But the insight I'=
m raising is not about that anyway.  It's about the flaw in concluding too =
much from an attempt to optimize an objective about what a particular algor=
ithm can accomplish.   If novelty might take longer without the walls, fitn=
ess will be even worse (longer time in deceptive traps).  In some sense, we=
 are flirting with the futility of all of search.  Novelty+fitness MOEA is =
likely a solution to some problems that neither one can solve alone, so it'=
s a promising idea, but I think novelty search is significant for more than=
 being a solution to something.  It is a symptom of a major interpretive pr=
oblem that stretches back into EC history.

ken  

--- In neat@yahoogroups.=
com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> Jean-Baptiste-
> 
> Thanks for writ=
ing this paper. It is really interesting.
> 
> I think it is particularly f=
ascinating how well Novelty + Fitness
> Multiobjective competed with pure N=
ovelty search on a problem designed to
> showcase the benefits of Novelty s=
earch.
> 
> My original instincts regarding Novelty search were that it was=
 a great way
> to overcome deception, but that there are huge classes of pr=
oblems where
> pure Novelty search will not work (e.g. take the problem you=
 and the
> original novelty search paper used, make it 1000 times larger, a=
nd get rid
> of the bottom and left walls up to the first walls that jut in=
). I had
> thought that a combination of Novelty + Fitness would be able to=
 handle such
> problems well, which your results strongly imply. Your paper=
 suggests that
> you will conduct tests on such problems. Have you tried th=
at yet? I look
> forward to seeing the results!
> 
> Cheers,
> Jeff Clune
>=
 
> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
> jclune@...
> www.msu=
.edu/~jclune
>

ups.com>
> > Subject: [neat] New paper "Novelty-based multiobjectivization"=

> > 
> >         Hello,
> > 
> > I just finished a paper for the IROS'09 w=
orkshop entitled "Exploring
> > New Horizons in Evolutionary Design of Robo=
ts"
> > [http://www.isir.fr/evoderob]. It's about novelty search and, since=
 we
> > talked a lot about it on this mailing-list, it could interest some =
of
> > you.
> > 
> > Here is the paper:
> > http://chronos.isir.upmc.fr/~mo=
uret/papers/novelty_based_multiobjectivization.
> > pdf
> > 
> > Abstract:
=
> >   Novelty search is a recent and promising approach to evolve
> >   neu=
ro-controllers, especially to drive robots. The main idea is to
> >   maxim=
ize the novelty of behaviors instead of the efficiency.
> >   However, aban=
doning the efficiency objective(s) may be too radical
> >   in many context=
s. In this paper, a Pareto-based multi-objective
> >   evolutionary algorit=
hm is employed to reconcile novelty search with
> >   objective-based optim=
ization by following a multiobjectivization
> >   process. Several multiobj=
ectivizations based on behavioral novelty
> >   and on behavioral diversity=
 are compared on a maze navigation
> >   task. Results show that the multio=
bjectivizations is better at
> >   fine-tuning behaviors than basic novelty=
 search while keeping a
> >   comparable number of iterations to converge.
=
> > 
> > Best regards,
> > -- 
> > Jean-Baptiste Mouret / Mandor
